Database API 1.5.1

com.google.code.gwt.database.client.service
Interface DataService

public interface DataService

Marks an interface as a DataService.

The DataService interface is the starting point for defining a SQL DataService. Start by defining your DataService like so (substitute anything in italics with your own values): 

 @Connection(name="shortname", version="1.0",
             description="diplayname", maxsize=max size in bytes)
 public interface MyDataService extends DataService {
   // ...
 }

Please make sure that you 1) extend this DataService interface, and 2) add a Connection annotation to it to specify the database connection parameters.

Next, specify the actual data services as interface methods. There are four kinds of DataService methods, like in the following code: 

 // 1. No resultset anticipated:
 @Update("INSERT INTO a_table (column_name) VALUES ({when.getTime()})")
 void insertValue(Date when, VoidCallback callback);
 
 // 2. A scalar value anticipated:
 @Select("SELECT COUNT(*) FROM a_table")
 void getValueCount(ScalarCallback<Integer> callback);
 
 // 3. A List of (row) items anticipated:
 @Select("SELECT * FROM a_table WHERE column_name >= {when.getTime()}")
 void getValuesFrom(Date when, ListCallback<GenericRow> callback);
 
 // 4. A List of ROWID's anticipated:
 @Update(sql="INSERT INTO a_table (column_name) VALUES ({_.getTime()})", foreach="dates")
 void insertValues(List dates, RowIdListCallback callback);

Before we take the different callbacks one-by-one, first this:

  • Each defined method in the interface must be annotated with either the Select or the Update annotation. The annotation specifies the SQL statement to execute whenever the method is called.
  • The specified SQL statement is executed within a single SQL transaction.
  • Use curly brackets to map the method's parameters to a value in the SQL statement.
  • You can re-use a parameter as much as you want.
  • You can enter Java expressions within the curly braces, as long as they evaluate to a single, primitive-like Object.

These are the callback types you can use:

  1. The 'void' callback. This callback doesn't do anything with the query resultSet, if any.
  2. The 'scalar' callback. This callback expects the resultSet to have exactly one record in the resultSet, with just one column of data (like from a COUNT(*) query). Any other records, or columns, are just ignored. There are only a few scalar types suitable for this callback: Integer, String, Boolean, Double, Float and Date.
  3. The 'list' callback. This type relays the complete resultSet as a List to the caller. The type parameter of the callback is the same as the type parameter on the returned List.
  4. The 'ROWIDs' callback. This type collects the ROWID's of inserted records and relays them to the caller. This callback only makes sense using the Update annotation.

Now that we have a DataService, this is how you use it: 

 MyDataService service = GWT.create(MyDataService.class);
 
 service.insertValue(new Date(), new VoidCallback() {
   public boolean onFailure(SQLError e) {
     return true;  // rollback transaction
   }
   public void onSuccess() {
     // What to do when transaction succeeded?
   }
 });

Due to the asynchronous nature of the Database API, we must employ callbacks instead of regular return values. Hopefully, the synchronous Database API makes its inroads in the near future.

See Also:
Connection, Select, Update, VoidCallback, ScalarCallback, ListCallback, RowIdListCallback, Wiki: User Guide

Method Summary
 Database getDatabase()
          Returns the Database instance associated with this DataService.
 

Method Detail

Database getDatabase()
Returns the Database instance associated with this DataService.
